thread.title: Think-tank queries PM’s ‘war on poverty’

title: Think-tank queries PM’s ‘war on poverty’
text:
Scientists sniffy over £600m flu medicines 
A Treasury spokesperson said that most working households would be better off after all the government’s welfare reforms come into force by 2017, but conceded that the next two years would see many families lose out. 
The prime minister used his party conference speech on Wednesday to set out a sweeping if policy-light account of how he wanted the Conservatives to address inequality and poverty over the next five years. 
But the think-tank’s analysis is a reminder that Mr Cameron’s rhetoric comes while the government is set to lay out more public spending cuts, which will be announced by George Osborne at the spending review on November 25. 
The Resolution Foundation defines household poverty as below 60 per cent of median income, a standard international measure that was used by the previous Labour government in its definition of child poverty. 
That definition, included in the Child Poverty Act (2010), has been criticised by Iain Duncan Smith, the work and pensions secretary, who is bringing forward legislation to change how the government measures child poverty. 
Mr Duncan Smith has criticised think-tank estimates of how his policies would affect household poverty. The Institute for Fiscal Studies suggested that figures for 2013-14 would increase, but the number fell according to official statistics published in June. 
The Resolution Foundation analysed the effects of several policies announced in the Budget, including the new higher minimum wage, a four-year freeze of working-age benefits and an increase in the rate at which tax credits are withdrawn as a worker’s earnings increase. 
As well as increasing the numbers of households in poverty, the think-tank also argued that the welfare changes reduce financial incentives to work. 
“Many of those looking forward to a pay rise this April [from the higher minimum wage] will soon learn that those gains will be dwarfed by reductions to tax credits”, said David Finch Senior Economic Analyst at the Resolution Foundation. 
“And by weakening work incentives in the benefits system, the government has made it even harder for families to earn their way out of poverty.” Related Topics
